question: At a stop sign, where must you stop if a stop line is painted?
choices: Anywhere before the intersection
Beside the stop sign post
At the painted stop line
Halfway into the intersection to see better
explanation: You must come to a complete stop at the painted stop line. If there’s no stop line, stop at the crosswalk; if none, at the edge of the sidewalk; if none, at the edge of the intersection.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Stopping

notes: Original question authored for this app. We do not copy third-party practice tests.

question: On a two-way road with no median, a school bus ahead of you stops with its upper red lights flashing. What must you do?
choices: Slow to 10 km/h and pass with caution
Stop at least 20 metres behind and remain stopped until the lights stop flashing and the stop arm retracts
Pass if no children are visible on the road
Stop only if you are approaching from the opposite direction
explanation: When a school bus activates its red flashing lights (and/or stop arm), you must stop. If you are behind the bus, stop at least 20 metres away and remain stopped until the red lights stop flashing and the stop arm retracts. On roads with a median, only vehicles behind the bus must stop.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Sharing the road with other road users (School buses)

notes: Original question; do not copy third-party practice tests.

question: At a four-way stop, two vehicles stop at exactly the same time. Who goes first?
choices: The larger vehicle goes first
The vehicle on the left goes first
The vehicle on the right goes first
Whoever flashes headlights first
explanation: If two vehicles stop at the same time at an all-way stop, the vehicle on the left must yield to the vehicle on the right.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Driving through intersections

notes: Original question aligned to the handbook rule.

question: When is it legal to make a right turn on a red light in Ontario?
choices: Anytime you signal
Only when a police officer waves you through
After a complete stop and only if there is no sign prohibiting it, and you yield to pedestrians and traffic
Only between sunrise and sunset
explanation: You may turn right on red after coming to a full stop, provided there is no sign prohibiting it and you yield to pedestrians and other road users.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Changing directions

question: When must you turn on your headlights in Ontario?
choices: Only after dark
From sunset exactly to sunrise only
Half an hour before sunset to half an hour after sunrise, and whenever visibility is under about 150 m (e.g., fog, rain, snow)
Only on highways
explanation: Headlights are required from one-half hour before sunset to one-half hour after sunrise, and any time poor light conditions prevent you from clearly seeing people or vehicles less than 150 metres away.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Getting ready to drive (Lighting)

notes: Original wording; aligns to lighting requirement.

question: A school crossing guard steps into the road holding a red-and-white stop sign. What must you do?
choices: Slow down and pass carefully if no children are on the crosswalk
Stop, then proceed if the guard waves only children across
Stop before the crossing and remain stopped until everyone, including the guard, has cleared the entire roadway and it is safe to go
Honk to alert others and proceed
explanation: You must stop before reaching the crossing and remain stopped until all people—including the school crossing guard—have cleared the entire roadway and it is safe to proceed.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Stopping (School crossings)
Driving near pedestrian crossovers and school crossings

notes: Original question; summarizes the rule for school crossings.

question: What is the minimum safe following distance under good conditions for most passenger vehicles?
choices: One second behind the vehicle ahead
Two seconds behind the vehicle ahead
Three car lengths at any speed
Five seconds only on highways
explanation: Use at least the two-second rule to maintain a safe following distance under good conditions. Increase the gap in poor weather or when visibility is low.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Safe and Responsible Driving (Following distance)

notes: Original question; aligns to handbook guidance.

question: Approaching a YIELD sign and cross traffic is present. What must you do?
choices: Proceed without stopping if you signal
Slow down, be prepared to stop, and yield the right-of-way to traffic and pedestrians; stop if needed
Always come to a complete stop for at least three seconds
Speed up to merge before other vehicles
explanation: A YIELD sign means you must slow down, be ready to stop, and give the right-of-way to traffic on the road you’re entering and to pedestrians. Stop if required.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Driving through intersections (Yielding right-of-way)

notes: Original question for Prep test G1. We align to the Official MTO Driver’s Handbook and do not copy third-party practice tests.

question: What does this sign mean?
choices: Left turns allowed only at night
No left turn permitted at any time
Left turn lane begins ahead
U-turns allowed with caution
explanation: A red circle with a slash always means a prohibition. The arrow pointing left with a slash means no left turns are allowed.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Traffic Signs (Regulatory Signs)

notes: Original question aligned to Ontario signage.

question: What does this sign indicate?
choices: Recommended maximum speed 80 km/h
Minimum speed 80 km/h
Maximum legal speed 80 km/h under ideal conditions
Speed must always be 80 km/h regardless of conditions
explanation: A white rectangular sign with black numerals indicates the maximum legal speed in kilometres per hour under ideal driving conditions.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Traffic Signs (Regulatory Signs)

notes: Original question aligned with Ontario speed limit signage.

question: Approaching a roundabout, what must you do before entering?
choices: Enter quickly and claim your lane
Stop in the entry lane even if no one is coming
Yield to traffic already in the roundabout and to pedestrians, and enter when there is a safe gap
Signal left and enter immediately
explanation: Slow down and yield to circulating traffic and pedestrians. Enter only when there is a safe gap; then signal right when exiting.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Roundabouts

notes: Original question aligned to the roundabout entry/yield rules.

question: On a road divided by a median, a school bus on the opposite side stops with red lights flashing. What must you do?
choices: Stop immediately
Proceed with caution; only vehicles behind the bus must stop
Honk and pass
Stop for 3 seconds, then proceed
explanation: On roads with a median, only vehicles behind the bus must stop for its flashing red lights. Opposing traffic may proceed with caution.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Sharing the road (School buses)

notes: Original question; complements the earlier school-bus scenario.

question: At a pedestrian crossover (PXO) with flashing beacons, when can you proceed?
choices: As soon as the pedestrian steps onto the curb on your half of the road
After slowing and sounding the horn
Only after pedestrians have completely crossed and fully left the roadway, and it’s safe
Anytime if you are turning right
explanation: You must stop for pedestrians at PXOs and remain stopped until they have completely crossed and are fully off the roadway. Proceed only when it’s safe.

sources.title: Ontario — Driving near pedestrian crossovers and school crossings

notes: Original question aligned to PXO rules.

question: This sign appears ahead. What does it warn you about?
choices: Bicycles are prohibited on this road
Expect cyclists; bicycle traffic may be crossing or sharing the road
Shared-use path begins; motor vehicles must stop
Bicycle lane ends; merge right immediately
explanation: A yellow diamond bicycle symbol is a warning sign to watch for cyclists and be prepared to slow down or yield as needed.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Traffic signs (Warning signs)

notes: Original question aligned to Ontario warning sign conventions.

question: What does this regulatory sign mean?
choices: Pedestrian crossover ahead
School crossing ahead
No pedestrians are allowed beyond this point
Pedestrians must yield to vehicles
explanation: A pedestrian symbol within a red circle with a slash means pedestrians are prohibited beyond that sign.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Traffic signs (Regulatory signs)

notes: Original question; matches Ontario regulatory prohibition style.

question: You see this sign at the entrance to a roadway. What must you do?
choices: Proceed slowly and keep right
Enter only if traffic is light
Do not enter — road is for traffic in the opposite direction
Stop and then proceed if clear
explanation: The red circle with a white horizontal bar means DO NOT ENTER — you are facing opposing traffic (e.g., the wrong end of a one-way).

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Traffic signs (Regulatory signs)

notes: Original question; aligns to Ontario 'Do Not Enter' meaning.

question: This sign shows two cars side-by-side within a red circle. What does it mean?
choices: Passing is allowed if you signal
No passing — you must not overtake other vehicles here
Use the left lane only
Keep right except to pass
explanation: A red circle is a prohibition. The two-car symbol indicates NO PASSING — do not overtake other vehicles where this sign applies.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Safe & Responsible Driving (Passing) and Regulatory signs

notes: Original question; ties sign meaning to passing rules.

question: You see this circular blue sign with white arrows before a roundabout. What should you do?
choices: Enter quickly and signal left
Keep right, travel counter-clockwise and yield to traffic already in the roundabout and to pedestrians
Stop and wait for a green signal
U-turn is mandatory at the next exit
explanation: Approach slowly, keep right of the central island, yield to pedestrians and to vehicles already in the roundabout, and enter when there is a safe gap.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Roundabouts

notes: Original question; pairs the sign with the roundabout entry/yield rule.

question: A school bus coming toward you has its upper red lights flashing (no median). What must you do?
choices: Proceed at 20 km/h with caution
Stop a safe distance away and remain stopped until the red lights stop flashing and the stop arm retracts
Only slow down if children are visible
Stop only if you are within 20 metres of the bus
explanation: On roads without a median, vehicles in both directions must stop for a school bus with red lights flashing and remain stopped until the lights stop and the stop arm retracts.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Sharing the road with school buses

notes: Original question; complements the earlier school-bus item with the opposite-direction scenario.

question: You see this sign ahead. What does it mean for traffic on your approach?
choices: Detour ahead — reduce speed to 30 km/h
Road closed to all traffic — do not proceed
No stopping on this road
Temporary construction access permitted
explanation: A ROAD CLOSED sign means the roadway is closed to traffic. Do not proceed; follow posted detours or instructions.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Traffic signs (Temporary conditions / regulatory signs)

notes: Original question written for Prep test G1. We align to the Official MTO Driver’s Handbook and do not copy other practice tests.

question: When must seat belts be worn in Ontario?
choices: Only on highways
Whenever the vehicle is moving
Only when driving over 50 km/h
Only when passengers are present
explanation: Drivers and passengers must wear a seat belt whenever the vehicle is moving. The driver is responsible for passengers under 16.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Safe and Responsible Driving (Seat belts)

notes: Original question created for Prep Test G1.

question: On a multi-lane highway, which lane should you normally drive in?
choices: Left lane at all times
Right lane except when passing
Centre lane for steady speed
Whichever lane has less traffic
explanation: Keep to the right except when passing or preparing for a left turn. Use the left lane mainly for passing.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Safe and Responsible Driving (Lane discipline)

notes: Original wording by Prep Test G1.

question: A sign warns “Bridge Freezes Before Road.” What should you do?
choices: Accelerate to cross quickly
Brake hard before the bridge
Slow down and avoid sudden moves on the bridge
Drive in the centre of the road
explanation: Bridges freeze first. Reduce speed and avoid hard braking or sudden steering on the bridge.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Adverse conditions (Winter driving)

question: Your tires begin to hydroplane on a wet road. What should you do?
choices: Brake hard and steer sharply
Ease off the gas and steer straight until you regain traction
Accelerate to regain grip
Turn the wheel back and forth to shake off water
explanation: Ease off the accelerator and keep the wheels straight until traction returns.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Adverse conditions (Wet roads)

question: How far ahead should you signal before turning or changing lanes?
choices: At least 30 metres (100 ft)
Just as you turn the wheel
Five car lengths away
Only when someone is behind you
explanation: Signal well in advance — at least 30 metres (100 feet) before a turn or lane change.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Changing Directions

question: When should you use your horn?
choices: To greet a friend
To warn others of possible danger
When the light turns green
When angry at other drivers
explanation: Use your horn only to warn others when necessary to avoid a collision.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Safe and Responsible Driving (Communication)

question: A flag person is directing traffic in a construction zone. You must:
choices: Follow the flag person’s instructions at all times
Ignore them if a traffic light shows green
Proceed slowly without stopping
Sound your horn before passing
explanation: Flag persons override signs and signals. You must obey their directions.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Construction zones

question: If a driver under 21 has any alcohol in their system while driving, they:
choices: May receive only a warning
Are subject to zero tolerance and licence suspension
May continue if accompanied by an adult
Are exempt on weekends
explanation: Ontario has a zero BAC requirement for drivers under 21 and for novice drivers (G1/G2).

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Impaired driving

question: You feel drowsy while driving at night. What should you do?
choices: Open the window and turn up music
Pull over safely and rest
Drive faster to finish sooner
Drink coffee and keep going
explanation: If you’re sleepy, stop in a safe place and rest. Fatigue is dangerous.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Fatigue and safe driving

question: When driving in dense fog, you should:
choices: Use high-beam headlights
Use low-beam headlights and reduce speed
Turn off lights completely
Drive close to centre line for guidance
explanation: Use low beams in fog and slow down; high beams reflect back and reduce visibility.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Adverse conditions (Fog)

question: Children under 9 kg (20 lb) must be secured in:
choices: A booster seat
A rear-facing child car seat
A seat belt only
A front passenger seat with airbag on
explanation: Infants under 9 kg (20 lb) must travel in a rear-facing child car seat.

sources.title: Ontario — Child car seats

question: If your turn signals fail, how can you signal a right turn by hand?
choices: Left arm straight out
Left arm out and bent up at the elbow
Left arm out and bent down
Wave your hand in a circle
explanation: Left arm out and bent up at 90° means a right turn by hand signal.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Signalling

question: Before changing lanes, you should:
choices: Signal and immediately move over
Check mirrors and blind spots by looking over your shoulder
Rely only on your mirrors
Sound your horn
explanation: Always check mirrors and blind spots by shoulder check before changing lanes.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Changing Lanes

question: At an intersection with no marked crosswalk, where should pedestrians cross?
choices: Anywhere they wish
In line with sidewalks on either side
Halfway across the intersection
At a diagonal angle
explanation: Pedestrians cross in a straight line between sidewalks even if no lines are painted.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Pedestrian Safety

question: When following a motorcycle, you should:
choices: Follow closely to see better
Maintain at least a 2-second distance or more
Use your high beams to be seen
Pass immediately
explanation: Allow extra space when following motorcycles; they can stop and maneuver quickly.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Sharing the Road (Motorcycles)

question: You approach a snowplow working on the highway. What should you do?
choices: Stay well back and do not pass until safe and clear
Pass immediately on the right
Sound horn to get it to move over
Flash high beams to signal you are behind
explanation: Stay well back; snowplows throw snow and sand and may obscure your view. Pass only when safe and legal.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Adverse conditions (Winter Driving)

question: If a tire blows out while driving, what should you do first?
choices: Brake hard immediately to stop the car
Hold the wheel firmly, ease off the accelerator, and steer straight
Shift to Neutral and turn off the ignition
Accelerate slightly to regain control
explanation: Grip the wheel, ease off the gas, and steer straight until you can slow and move off the road safely.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Emergency situations (Tire blowouts)

question: Your brake pedal suddenly goes to the floor and braking power is lost. What is your best immediate action?
choices: Pump the brake pedal several times and downshift to lower gears to slow the vehicle
Turn off the engine at once
Pull the parking brake hard in one motion
Swerve onto the shoulder immediately
explanation: Pump the brakes to build pressure and use engine braking. Apply parking brake gradually if needed; steer to a safe stop.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Emergency situations (Brake failure)

question: Your accelerator sticks and the engine races. What should you do first?
choices: Turn the key to lock to stall the engine
Shift to Neutral, steer to a safe place, and apply brakes
Turn on cruise control to stabilize speed
Shut off all electrical systems
explanation: Shift to Neutral to disconnect engine power, steer to a safe place, and brake smoothly. Do not switch ignition to lock while moving.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Emergency situations (Stuck accelerator)

question: An emergency vehicle with flashing lights and siren is approaching from behind on a two-way road. What must you do?
choices: Maintain your speed so you don’t block traffic
Pull as far to the right as possible and stop until it has passed
Speed up to stay ahead of it
Stop in the left lane
explanation: Safely pull to the right edge and stop, yielding to the emergency vehicle. Check for additional emergency vehicles before rejoining traffic.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Sharing the road (Emergency vehicles)

question: At a four-way stop, a pedestrian is crossing ahead of you and a car on your right arrives at the same time. What should you do?
choices: Go first because you arrived at the same time
Wave the other driver through and ignore the pedestrian
Yield to the pedestrian first, then allow the car on your right to go before you
Proceed quickly before anyone else moves
explanation: Pedestrians in the crosswalk go first. After they clear, the car on your right has the right-of-way at a four-way stop.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Driving through intersections

notes: Original intersection question for Prep test G1.

question: When using an entrance ramp to merge onto a freeway, you should:
choices: Stop at the end of the ramp and wait for a large gap
Drive slowly and merge at whatever speed feels comfortable
Use the acceleration lane to match the speed of highway traffic and merge when safe
Signal only after you have already merged
explanation: Use the acceleration lane to reach the speed of traffic on the freeway, signal, shoulder check, and merge when there is a safe gap.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Freeway driving

question: When leaving a freeway, when should you slow down to the exit ramp speed?
choices: On the freeway lane before the exit
Only after you are on the exit ramp and see the lower speed posted
As soon as you see the first exit sign
Only if there is traffic behind you
explanation: Maintain freeway speed until you are actually on the exit ramp, then slow to the posted ramp speed.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Freeway driving

question: When parking uphill on a road with a curb, how should you turn your front wheels?
choices: Toward the curb
Straight ahead
Away from the curb
It does not matter
explanation: Uphill with a curb: turn the wheels away from the curb so if the vehicle rolls, the front tire will roll back into the curb.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Parking

notes: Original question about parking on hills.

question: When parking downhill on a road with a curb, how should you turn your front wheels?
choices: Toward the curb
Straight ahead
Away from the curb
Always use the parking brake only
explanation: Downhill with a curb: turn your wheels toward the curb so the vehicle would roll into the curb, not into traffic.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Parking

question: When parking on a hill with no curb, how should you turn your wheels?
choices: Always straight ahead
So the vehicle would roll away from the road if it moved
So the vehicle would roll into the road if it moved
Wheel direction does not matter
explanation: Without a curb, turn your wheels so the vehicle would roll off the road, not into traffic, if it moved.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Parking

question: You are approaching a railway crossing with flashing red lights and gates lowering. What must you do?
choices: Drive around the gates if you don’t see a train
Stop at least 5 metres from the crossing and remain stopped until the lights stop and the gates are fully raised
Slow down but proceed carefully
Stop, then proceed once you think it’s safe, even if the lights are still flashing
explanation: You must stop at least 5 metres from the tracks and remain stopped until the lights stop flashing and gates are fully raised.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Railway crossings

question: In a school zone where a lower speed limit is posted with times of day, when does that lower limit apply?
choices: Only when children are visible
Only if traffic is heavy
During the times shown on the sign (for example, school hours on school days)
Only in summer
explanation: Obey the reduced speed during the times shown on the sign, often on school days during arrival and dismissal times.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Speed limits

question: In a construction zone, fines for speeding are:
choices: Reduced because traffic is slower
The same as any other road
Doubled compared to the same offence outside a work zone
Only applied if workers are present
explanation: Speeding fines are higher—often doubled—in designated construction zones, even if workers are not always visible.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Construction zones

question: The shoulder of the road is mainly for:
choices: Driving faster than traffic
Passing slower vehicles
Emergency stopping or breakdowns when necessary
Parking all day
explanation: The shoulder is not a travel lane; it is mainly for emergency stops or breakdowns when necessary and allowed.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Safe and Responsible Driving (Road position)

question: When backing out of a driveway into a roadway, you must:
choices: Rely on your mirrors only
Back out quickly to avoid blocking traffic
Yield to all pedestrians, cyclists, and vehicles on the road
Honk the horn and back out without stopping
explanation: When backing out, you must yield to road users and ensure the way is clear before moving.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Safe and Responsible Driving (Backing up)

question: When reversing straight, the best way to look is:
choices: In the rear-view mirror only
Over your right shoulder through the rear window while backing slowly
At the infotainment screen
Only in the side mirrors
explanation: Turn your body and look over your right shoulder through the back window while reversing slowly and checking around.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Backing up

question: You are turning left at an intersection and oncoming traffic is approaching. What should you do?
choices: Turn quickly in front of oncoming traffic
Move into the intersection and turn only when there is a safe gap or after the light turns yellow/red and oncoming traffic has stopped
Turn from the right lane to save time
Stop behind the crosswalk and wait only for the green arrow
explanation: Creep into the intersection when safe, yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians, and complete your turn only when there is a safe gap.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Turning left

question: What is the correct order when changing lanes?
choices: Signal, shoulder check, mirror check, move
Mirror check, signal, shoulder check, move when safe
Move, then signal, then mirror check
Shoulder check only
explanation: Check mirrors, signal, check your blind spot (shoulder check), then move into the lane when safe.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Changing lanes

question: When should you signal at a roundabout?
choices: Signal left while driving around the circle
Signal right just before you take your exit
Do not signal at all
Signal hazard lights while inside
explanation: Signal right as you pass the exit before the one you intend to take, to show you are leaving the roundabout.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Roundabouts

question: When passing parked cars where cyclists may ride, you should:
choices: Drive very close to the parked cars to leave room on your right
Leave enough space so you won’t hit an opened door (avoid the door zone)
Honk to warn parked drivers
Use your high beams
explanation: Leave space between your vehicle and parked cars so you will not strike a suddenly opened door or a cyclist.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Sharing the road with cyclists

question: When passing a cyclist, what is the best practice?
choices: Pass as closely as possible to stay in your lane
Slow down and leave plenty of space, changing lanes if needed and safe
Honk until the cyclist moves aside
Pass on the right of the cyclist
explanation: Slow down and leave a wide space when passing cyclists, moving partly or fully into the next lane when safe.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Sharing the road with cyclists

question: An animal suddenly runs onto the road. What is the safest general response?
choices: Swerve sharply into the opposite lane
Brake firmly in a straight line and be prepared to stop if safe
Turn off your headlights
Accelerate to get past faster
explanation: Brake in a straight line and avoid swerving into oncoming traffic or off the road, which can cause a more serious collision.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Safe and Responsible Driving (Hazards)

question: Black ice is:
choices: Ice that is safe to drive on
A thin, nearly invisible layer of ice on the road
Ice that only forms in the daytime
Ice you see only on gravel roads
explanation: Black ice is a nearly invisible sheet of ice on the pavement. Slow down and drive smoothly in conditions where it may form.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Adverse conditions (Winter driving)

question: Why should you avoid using high-beam headlights in fog?
choices: They are not bright enough
They reflect off fog and reduce your ability to see ahead
They overheat the bulbs
They use too much fuel
explanation: High beams reflect off fog droplets and can make it harder to see. Use low beams and slow down.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Adverse conditions (Fog)

question: If your vehicle breaks down on a highway, what should you do first when you stop on the shoulder?
choices: Get out and stand beside the vehicle
Park as far off the roadway as possible, turn on hazard lights, and stay inside with seat belt fastened if it’s safe
Open the hood and stand in front of the car
Walk along the highway to get help
explanation: Pull as far off the road as possible, switch on hazard lights, and stay inside if it’s safe until help arrives.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Emergency situations

question: In a vehicle with ABS (antilock braking system), how should you brake in an emergency stop?
choices: Pump the brake pedal rapidly
Press the brake pedal firmly and hold it while steering
Use only the parking brake
Shift to Neutral and coast
explanation: With ABS, apply firm, continuous pressure on the brake pedal and steer in the direction you want to go.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Emergency braking (ABS)

question: In a vehicle without ABS, how should you brake on a slippery surface to avoid skidding?
choices: Brake as hard as possible and hold
Apply and release the brakes (threshold braking) to avoid wheel lockup
Use only the parking brake
Turn off the engine while braking
explanation: On slippery roads without ABS, brake just enough to slow without locking the wheels, releasing and reapplying if they start to lock.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Emergency braking

question: At night, when should you dim your high-beam headlights for an oncoming vehicle?
choices: When you are about one block away (approximately 150 metres)
Only when the other driver flashes their lights
When the other vehicle is right in front of you
Never; high beams should stay on
explanation: Dim your high beams when within about 150 metres of oncoming traffic so you don’t blind other drivers.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Night Driving

question: A vehicle is following you too closely (tailgating). What is a safe response?
choices: Brake suddenly to warn them
Speed up to get away
Gradually slow down and increase your space in front, then change lanes when safe to let them pass
Ignore them completely
explanation: Don’t brake suddenly. Increase your following distance ahead and, when safe, move to another lane or allow the tailgater to pass.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Safe and Responsible Driving (Space management)

question: If another driver behaves aggressively or with road rage, you should:
choices: React the same way to defend yourself
Make eye contact and gesture back
Stay calm, avoid eye contact, and give them space
Follow them to confront them
explanation: Stay calm, avoid escalating, and give aggressive drivers space. Do not engage or retaliate.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Safe and Responsible Driving (Attitude)

question: Drugs that can impair your driving include:
choices: Only illegal drugs
Illegal drugs, some prescription medications, and some over-the-counter drugs
Only alcohol and tobacco
Only drugs taken without food
explanation: Many substances, including some prescription and over-the-counter medications, can impair your driving. Always read labels and follow medical advice.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Impaired driving

question: A G1 driver must be accompanied by a fully licensed driver who:
choices: Is at least 16 years old with any licence
Has at least four years of driving experience and a blood alcohol level of less than 0.05
Has a motorcycle licence only
Has a G2 licence with one year of experience
explanation: G1 drivers must be accompanied by a fully licensed driver with at least four years of driving experience and a blood alcohol level under 0.05.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Graduated licensing

question: What is the legal blood alcohol level for a G1 or G2 driver while driving?
choices: Below the Criminal Code limit only
0.05 or under
Zero—no alcohol in the blood
Any level is acceptable with supervision
explanation: Novice drivers (G1, G2) must have a blood alcohol concentration of zero while driving.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Graduated licensing & Impaired driving

question: Most G1 drivers are not allowed to drive on:
choices: Any city street
Any road with a speed limit over 60 km/h
Certain high-speed expressways such as 400-series highways, unless accompanied by an approved driving instructor in a dual-control car
Any road at night
explanation: G1 drivers are restricted from certain high-speed expressways unless with an approved driving instructor in a dual-control car.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Graduated licensing restrictions

question: Before driving, how should you position your seat?
choices: So you are far from the controls and must stretch your legs fully
So you can reach the pedals and controls comfortably with a slight bend in your arms and legs
As close to the steering wheel as possible
Reclined far back to be relaxed
explanation: Sit close enough to reach the pedals and controls comfortably with a slight bend in your arms and legs for good control.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Getting ready to drive (Seating position)

question: When should you adjust your mirrors?
choices: While driving at highway speed
Before you start driving, when the vehicle is stopped
Only at night
Only if they are dirty
explanation: Adjust mirrors before driving so you have a clear view behind and to the sides.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Getting ready to drive (Mirrors)

question: Which action helps reduce the risk of hydroplaning?
choices: Driving faster in the rain
Using worn tires
Reducing speed on wet roads and ensuring tires are in good condition
Coasting in Neutral
explanation: Slowing down in wet conditions and having good tires with proper tread helps prevent hydroplaning.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Adverse conditions (Wet roads)

question: Which of the following is an example of a dangerous distraction while driving?
choices: Checking mirrors regularly
Scanning the road ahead
Texting or using a handheld phone
Adjusting your seat before driving
explanation: Using a handheld phone or texting while driving is a dangerous distraction and is illegal in Ontario.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Distracted driving

question: You see a pedestrian standing at the edge of an uncontrolled crosswalk. What should you do?
choices: Speed up to pass before they step out
Be prepared to yield and allow the pedestrian to cross safely
Ignore them because there is no traffic light
Honk to discourage them from crossing
explanation: Be prepared to yield to pedestrians at crosswalks and allow them to cross safely.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Pedestrian safety

question: A school bus ahead of you activates its upper flashing amber (yellow) lights. What does this mean?
choices: You must stop immediately
The bus is about to stop to load or unload children; be prepared to stop
You may pass at full speed
The bus is out of service
explanation: Flashing amber lights mean the bus is preparing to stop. Slow down and be ready to stop when the red lights come on.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — School buses

question: A rectangular sign with an arrow curving around a traffic island and the words 'KEEP RIGHT' means:
choices: You may pass on either side
Traffic must keep to the right of the island or obstruction
Left turns only
Right turn prohibited
explanation: The sign means you must keep right of the traffic island or obstruction.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Regulatory signs

question: A yellow diamond sign showing a winding arrow means:
choices: Road ahead is straight
Road ahead has a series of curves; reduce speed and drive with caution
Only one sharp curve ahead
Paved shoulder ahead
explanation: A winding road sign warns of several curves ahead. Slow down and be prepared for changing direction.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Warning signs

question: A yellow diamond sign showing a narrowing shape means:
choices: Wide bridge ahead
Road narrows or narrow bridge ahead; be prepared to slow and use caution
Road widens ahead
Divided highway begins
explanation: A road narrows or narrow-bridge warning sign means lanes may become narrower; reduce speed and pass with care.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Warning signs

question: A yellow diamond sign showing one line splitting around a centre shape means:
choices: Two-way traffic ahead
Divided highway begins; keep to the right of the median
Divided highway ends
Passing allowed in both directions
explanation: The sign warns that a divided highway begins and you must keep to the right of the median or barrier.

sources.title: Official MTO Driver’s Handbook — Warning signs (Divided highway begins)
